description.text: Simple 2-piece sliding privacy shield / camera cover for your laptop. Glue it on.

Print out the two pieces using layers no thicker than 100 microns. Place the sliding portion inside the track so that the little grippy slits are poking out through the slot -- that's the front. Use a piece of tape to keep it aligned while you carefully apply any suitable glue or tape to the perimeter of the larger piece. Apply it to the laptop and remove the tape and you are done.  
I tried using double-sided tape but it didn't seem to stick to the ABS I was using, so I ended up using hot glue, admittedly not ideal (and not that pretty). This sticks very well but be careful not to glue the two printed pieces together. Try to get glue all the way around, as any gaps can result in the sliding piece rotating and poking through there. This has to be extremely thin to still allow your laptop to close, which doesn't leave a lot of room for a good positively-gripping track.  
It could be improved by increasing the height of it so there's more area for contact. It could also be modified to look a little nicer and more polished, but I did this really quick.

comments.text: Great idea, but, does the laptop close poperly?
comments.author: Elferiante

comments.text: It does. I've installed it on probably 4 laptops over the years and all closed. One laptop needed just a bit more force to latch but closed fine. Lots of laptops have a thin gasket around the rim and the privacy shield is thinner than that.

title: Micro Scisky Flight Controller Mount Case

description.text:
As anyone who has done a build with the Micro Scisky can attest, it does not lend itself to easily mounting flat on the frame. I tried it this way for a while, but after a few crashes whilst trying to learn FPV, I had a need to protect the FC from damage. This thing is the result. The base has standoffs to allow the controller to sit flat without the need to get creative with the mounting tape. The base can be used stand-alone, or with the top for added protection.

The top is designed to accommodate micro JST connectors on the motor wires. The Scisky has what I would consider a design flaw where the motor pads are in opposite directions. I just soldered all the micro JST connectors on in the same orientation and swapped the motor wires around in the female connectors on two of the motors. If the connectors are mounted to the board such that wire swapping is not required, the top probably will not fit, as it was designed for all connectors mounted in the same orientation.

This page is mainly for reference. Most users will want this simpler solution which parses strings containing OpenSCAD formulas: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2295309

One of the features that OpenSCAD is lacking is the ability to pass functions to modules or to functions. This is a quick-and-dirty proof-of-concept solution to the not uncommon problem of wanting to pass a mathematical formula to a module or function: an eval() function that evaluates expressions in a simple LISP-inspired language that supports all of the OpenSCAD mathematical operators. The evaluation is moderately fast: about 10,000 evaluations of the sample formula below per second on my laptop. The downside is that it's pretty inconvenient to write expressions in this language.

Call the function with: eval(expression, variables). Here, variables is a table of variable values, where each line of the table has the name of the variable followed by its value, e.g., [["x", 12.3], ["y", 7]].

An expression is one the following:

  1. a string naming a variable and expressing the value of that variable
  2. a vector of the form ["'", value] expressing the given literal value (e.g., ["'", [12,3]] expresses the vector [12,3])
  3. for convenience, a number expressing itself (e.g., 12.3)
  4. a vector of the form [operator argument1 argument2 ...]

For instance, the OpenSCAD formula 3*(x*pow(y,3)-pow(x,3)*y) is expressed with ["*", 3, [ "-", ["*", "x", ["^", "y", 3]], ["*", ["^", "x", 3], "y"] ]].

The operators supported are:

  • The binary operations +, -, *, /, %, <, <=, >, >=, ==, !=, &&, || and the unary - and ! with the same meanings as in OpenSCAD
  • The binary power operator ^ or pow with the same meaning as OpenSCAD's pow(x,y)
  • The unary degree-based trigonometric operators cos, sin, tan, acos, asin and atan and the binary atan2 with the same meaning as in OpenSCAD
  • The radian-based versions COS, SIN, TAN, ACOS, ASIN, ATAN and ATAN2
  • The functions abs, ceil, cross, exp, floor, ln, len, log, max, min, norm, rands, round and sign with the same meanings as in OpenSCAD
  • The ternary operator ?, where ["?", argument1, argument2, argument3] works like OpenSCAD's argument1 ? argument2 : argument3
  • The binary operator # that retrieves an element from a vector: ["#", argument1, argument2] works like OpenSCAD's argument1[argument2]
  • The variadic operator [ that forms a vector from its arguments. E.g., ["[", 3, 4, "x"] yields the vector [3,4,x]
  • The unary or variadic operators max and min; when given a single argument, that argument is assumed to be a vector to calculate the maximum or minimum of; when given multiple arguments, we get the maximum or minimum of all the arguments
  • The variadic operator concat which concatenates all of its arguments
  • The binary or ternary operator range which corresponds to OpenSCAD [argument1:argument2] or [argument1:argument2:argument3]
  • The ternary operator gen which provides a generator expression. Do ["gen", variable, range, subexpression] to generate a vector obtained by iterating subexpression over range while varying the value of the variable indicated (variable is an expression that should evaluate to a string). (UNTESTED)
    • The ternary operator let: ["let", variableName, value, expression] which evaluates expression under the added assumption that variableName is a string naming a variable whose value is value; e.g., ["let", ["'", "x", 3], ["+", "x", 1]] assigns 3 to the variable named "x", and then calculates x+1

Currently, unknown operators return the operator itself, but this behavior cannot be counted on.

The OpenSCAD file contains a demo which draws Borromean rings or a (primitive) 3D function plot.

Update:

  1. The variable system has been overhauled. The let operator has been explained.
  2. The variable system has been overhauled again: the dollar sign operator has been removed.

My Tacoma has matching cargo storage boxes built into each side of the bed near the tailgate. I wanted a way to attach a cargo net for holding groceries at the rear of the bed and figured that I could reuse the bolts that hold the storage boxes in. I decided to add cavities to provide bungee cord capability as well.

There are two designs, each with a left and right bracket. The one marked Tacoma is specifically made to fit around the plastic lip on the Tacoma's storage boxes. If you have a different truck you may wish to use the flat design.

Here's the cargo net I used:
https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00076QA4C

Update 6/2/2017

Had two of the strap pins snap under a heavy load so made a modified design that I'm uploading here, marked _v2. Let me know if you're using these and how they're working out for you. _v3 has enlarged tabs for added strength, but might not work if you don't have that much stretch in your cargo net.

Update 6/12/2017

Added additional supports around the screw holes because I had one piece bend under load. This should add some strength. Note that Tacoma models are marked "taco", they are made specifically to fit around the bed compartments to keep them from spinning around.

Update 8/2/2017

Had a few tie-downs fail in a few ways so I've completely redesigned them for my Tacoma. I've moved the screw hole to the center and added a lip to keep them from spinning, as well as strengthened the strap connectors. Finally, I've started printing everything in PetG. PLA cannot handle the Texas heat and sun outdoors!
Yet again I was bored.
DPT100 Test part

This is a tool designed to be used in long exposures. It spins a disc with open segments in front of a camera lens to interrupt a long exposure in intervals. This creates a unique look in light trails and any other technique used in lightpainting.

This tool uses a geared 12V dc motor with around 720RPM with a standard PWM controller.
The controller potentiometer knob is mounted outside the box along with a power plug and a switch for power. The discs are separated to be printable but need at least 300x200 print area.

The slit disc right is actually a little wrong, it should have been mirrored. I realized this after i printed and glued them together, but left them as they are because this creates a slight irregularity that adds character and makes the pattern look less artificial.

Example images show which type of disc created which type of effect.

German instructions can be found here:
http://forum.lightpainting-helpdesk.de/showthread.php?tid=298

Englisch instructions can be found here:
http://lightpaintingphotography.com/light-painting-photography/light-painting-interval-exposure/

print_settings.Notes:: Note that the original Burma-Shave signs came in 3, 4, and 5 sign jingles + the logo sign. If you want to print one of the shorter jingles, just create the Signs STL by filling out only the required number of signs in Customizer and use your host program to split the combined STL apart and delete the blank signs before slicing. The tall signpost, if printed with 100% infill, can be easily & cleanly trimmed to a shorter height for vertical mounting of shorter jingles. For short signposts, in all cases, print the appropriate number.

title: Customizable Miniature Burma-Shave Road Signs Redux

description.text:
I have vivid memories of the Burma-Shave roadway signs from family vacations in the late 1950s & early 1960s when I was a tike. My siblings and I would have contests to see who could spot a set first or read them from furthest away. Then we'd recite them in unison sign-by-sign as my lead-footed Dad roared by them (SLOW DOWN PA/SAKES ALIVE/MA MISSED SIGNS/FOUR AND FIVE/BURMA-SHAVE). They definitely helped keep kids occupied on roadtrips.

I immediately fell in love with TheNewHobbyist's "Customizable Miniature Burma-Shave Road Sign" (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:751540) when I saw it and used it as a basis for this remix. Thanks, TNH! Having a single extruder printer, I wanted to be able to print the signs and signpost(s) seperately, as well as have the option of printing short signposts so one can lay the signs out horizontally, in sequence, like they were on the roadside's of America. Also wanted to be able to vary the size of the text on individual signs in a set as these mixed word sizes were the way the originals were painted. These modifications were implemented in OpenSCAD and then uploaded to Customizer. The signs are a snug press-fit on the signposts and don't require adhesive. If you have a single extruder printer, pause your print before the text begins to print and change filament to create the contrasting text color on the signs. If you slice the signs at a layer height of 0.20mm, this pause will be between layer 18 and layer 19. Recommend that you use 20% infill on the signs and 100% infill on the signposts.

For more historical info on the Burma-Shave roadway signs see:

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Burma-Shave

See the full Burma-Shave sign jingle archive from the 1920s to the 1960s & find your favorites for a Make!:

http://burma-shave.org/jingles/

Printer:

Sunhokey 2015 Prusa i3

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.20mm

Infill:

20%

Notes:

Note that the original Burma-Shave signs came in 3, 4, and 5 sign jingles + the logo sign. If you want to print one of the shorter jingles, just create the Signs STL by filling out only the required number of signs in Customizer and use your host program to split the combined STL apart and delete the blank signs before slicing. The tall signpost, if printed with 100% infill, can be easily & cleanly trimmed to a shorter height for vertical mounting of shorter jingles. For short signposts, in all cases, print the appropriate number.

description.text: Printed a pink Smiling Owl (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1320992) for my wife that looked like it would make a good night light. So, I took this cool Trunk Planter for a cactus (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:292837), modified it to fit an LED lamp from Ikea (http://www.ikea.com/us/en/catalog/products/50302670/), and further modified it to tightly hold on to the Smiling Owl. Voila! Pink reading light. It's much too bright for a night light. A lower wattage LED, or variable brightness LED, would make it better for a night light. Still, looks great and my wife is happy. I also painted the stump to highlight some details.

This is an ongoing exercise to design 3d printable parts for each mechanical movement in the book "507 Mechanical Movements" by Henry T. Brown (published 1868). The latest Moments are now mech 8 and 9. The general idea is to use a few readily available parts; M3 nuts/bolts/washers, string and a 3d printer (yeah i know) to implement each mech. the bits ought to print quickly and are obliged to be easily assembled. The philosophy is to conserve mind and material; easily conceived assemblies of simple components. All part are parametrically described in OpenSCAD. Currently parts for Mechanisms 1 thur 9 have been implemented. This is going to take a while so grab yourself a copy and join in.
http://507movements.com/
https://archive.org/details/fivehundredseven00browiala Here are a few other components to aid in the process...
-see Printable OpenBeam: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:224515
-see also QuickCorner for OpenBeam: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:225936

It all builds upon itself.  
Notes:  
Mechanical Moments are currently defined figures 1-10.  Moments in figures 7 thur 11 are assumed to be driven from the top.

comments.text: If the title of this project was fixed from "Moments" to "Movements" then people could find it better.
comments.author: CaptObvious

comments.text: You should throw up a list of already designed mechs so we can keep track of which ones are yet undesigned.
comments.author: fmc1228

comments.text: Hello and thanks for your comment.  The intention is to implement each mech in the order that it appears in the book.  I'll update the description to include the latest mech.  I'm happy to take requests if you simply can't wait to see one.  My goal is to do at least one mech a week.  Some mechs reuse earlier parts so development happens in fits and spurts.  Clearly at this pace it will take a while to get through them all, but time is something that we can always make more of.

description.text:
Peasants & plagues is an interesting variation from NateStraight, that I designed as a 3d model for my settler of catan game: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1238980. The roules for this variation can be found here:https://boardgamegeek.com/thread/96236/two-variants-peasants-plagues-and-towers-catan

The plague (reaper) has four pieces you need to assemble (hand, body, stand and scythe) by using glue.

Also the peasants each have two parts (road and peasant) that need to be glued together.

Due to the 3d-design of the tiles you have to play this variation slightly different:

  • the peasants can't be put on the tiles, so you can put them on the roads that surround the tiles and orient their faces towards the resource-tile that they are supposed to support.

Thank you nate for your idea and the description you made :-)

I don't own anything concerning the original Legend of Zelda franchise, or Nintendo. If I did, I probably wouldn't be sitting at college designing mediocre 3D prints xD. I haven't printed this design, so for anyone who does, I hope it turns out good.

print_settings.Notes:: http://www.uswaterrockets.com/construction_&_tutorials/3D_Printed_Star_Wars_Droid/tutorial.htm

title: Large Star Wars R2-D2 Astromech Droid Replica

description.text:
This is a nearly 1/4 scale size replica of the famous R2-D2 droid from Star Wars, designed to be assembled from components which will all fit in a 3D printer with a 120x120x120mm build volume. It was designed to be as detailed as possible, and has moveable legs and head. The center leg even retracts inside the body. This droid also has a secret ability that is revealed in this short video: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=PZ98NAstVqA

For a complete set of assembly instructions, please go to http://www.uswaterrockets.com/construction_&_tutorials/3D_Printed_Star_Wars_Droid/tutorial.htm

Note: if you print this model with the intention of charging any type of fee to another person for your services, you agree to give 150% of your fees to the current copyright holder of the robot. You can keep the change. Thank you.

Printer:

Monoprice Select Mini

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.1mm Layers for best results

Infill:

Whatever works best for you

Notes:

See the assembly instructions at http://www.uswaterrockets.com/construction_&_tutorials/3D_Printed_Star_Wars_Droid/tutorial.htm for a complete listing of printed components, and note that the parts were designed to use no support, except for one or two exceptions.
You can sand and paint this droid like any other plastic model kit. Use a color scheme from the films, or come up with your own ideas.

This model was designed completely from scratch, to get experience designing detailed and articulated models intended for FDM 3D printing. It was designed using Alibre 2011, and the models were rotated to optimal build orientation using Meshmixer.

comments.author: Magikmerlin

comments.text: I printed the dome without supports. The roof on the inside was a little coarse but it saved a lot of time because the support goes all the way up and adds a lot of printing time. The body is the only part that needs support and you're right, it has to go "everywhere" to make sure the cutouts for the arms and vents are supported. You will want to play with your support settings (the x and y distances) so that the support doesn't try and appear inside the grooves and panel gaps in the body. If support gets in those gaps, it is hard to get out. Glad you like my model! Enjoy!

comments.text: I get all my metric screws from amazon or hobbyking. You can get them for a few dollars for a bag of 50 or 100 (the more you buy, the lower the cost per screw). They also come in assortments. In a pinch you can also just buy a handful of the longest ones you need and then make the shorter ones from that by carefully cutting them to length with a hacksaw or dremel tool cutting wheel. When you cut them sometimes it's hard to get them to thread on correctly, but if you smooth out the cut part with a file it will get them working.

comments.text: The ankle is intentionally oversize to spread the slot apart and provide friction in the ankle joint. Without friction, the ankles would not hold the robot up on 2 legs. The ankles have a raised circular ridge around the pivot point on each side that can be sanded or shaved down in case the printer tolerances caused the fit to be excessively tight. comments.text: First, this is an AWESOME model.  And I do mean fantastic.  I love it.  In case this is of any use to anyone, I have so far printed all the middle leg parts, the torso and the dome on a Printrbot Plus.  I used PLA throughout.  For the leg parts, I went with 0.1mm 15% infill, 1.2mm shells at 70mm/s.  For the torso and dome, I went with 0.2mm, 10% infill, 1.2mm shells at 70mm/s.  Really very successful.  I am on Cura 15.04.  I used a brim and support settings to 'Everywhere' and that worked out really really well.  As soon as I have the rest done, I will post an 'I Made It'.  There really is no room inside the torso for much.  If you wanted to scale it up, get ready for long, long, long print times.  At my settings, my torso took 14 hours to print, the dome needed just shy of 9 hours.  I can see going to 1/2 scale by doubling the size of everything but again, the track in the center for retracting the center leg occupies a lot of space.  As is I think I have room to put (small) motors in the right and left feet, run a wire up the legs to a small RC receiver like the sort I would put in a conversion of a Guillows balsa plane.  I would put a planetary gear somewhere as part of the dome and mount that motor in the gap between the torso's inner surface and the middle leg track.  I think for a Remix, I might just do that.  The rest is circuitry and batteries I can stick in the dome itself.  Hmmmmmmmmmmmm.....
comments.author: USWaterRockets

comments.text: I think there is room for some motors inside, but I was more concerned with making the legs and feet articulated. If they were not moveble, the axles and pivots in the legs and shoulders could be removed and make space for a drive system. The center leg could be glued in the down position and the track removed, freeing up all the interior space.
comments.author: SkyRider

comments.text: I'm almost done printing now.  It looks fantastic.  Just a few small parts like the utility arm and the holo-projector are left.  Then it's on to prime and paint.  I think a scale up by about 1.5x would give me better room for motors and so on and yes, I'd like the center leg in the down position like a previous R2 I had built.  Somewhere in my archives is a model for a neck ring like you have but with a place for a central motor shaft so that I can mount a motor mid torso and allow the head to be controlled with an Arduino.  All this is for another day.  First, I need to get my R2 camera sentry done......
comments.author: USWaterRockets

comments.text: Thanks for the tip.  I checked the reddit forum and see others are having the same issue - some think it is a Cura bug?  In any case, I was able to get started with Cura 15.04 so for now that works OK.
comments.author: USWaterRockets

comments.text: What fill (if any) are you using on the parts?  Also what shell thickness?  I am new to 3d printing so I am not sure where to get these details.
comments.author: Sam1Cohen

comments.text: I used 2 perimeters which is 0.8mm thick shell on the printer I used with a 0.4mm nozzle. I also used 0.8mm top and bottom thicknesses. The infill is not critical, but makes for better parts with more strength and can make the top surfaces smoother because the infill supports the printing layers above. I wouldn't use less than 15%. Infill over 25% is probably a waste of plastic on this design. I hope you get it dialed in! Good luck!
comments.author: Sam1Cohen

comments.text: This looks like an incredible kit!  How tall does he stand (with center leg retracted, standing straight)?  The Diamond Comics "bank" quarter scale R2 fits well with the Jakks 18" line, but this guy would look amazing.
comments.author: KMToydarian

comments.text: The moving parts have detents in the model which let the legs stick in the center position with friction. The center leg has detents in the track for the leg to hold it in the up and down positions.
comments.author: KMToydarian

comments.text: Good Grief ObiWan!
comments.author: SkyRider

comments.text:
1) I hit the parts with primer to fill in the layer lines, then sanded them smooth, then painted. I didn't do any chemical smoothing, because there are a lot of fine details I thought might get rounded off. I'm not the best painter, and I'd love to see someone who builds models as their main hobby get their hands on this and airbrush it properly.
2) I think selling kits would violate Lucasfilm trademarks.
3) I spent so much time and filament perfecting this model that I have yet to try scaling it up. There's no reason it would not scale as big as a printer can print.

title: Prusa i3 Mk2 Spool Holder Fix
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
I got tired of our filament spool falling off our Prusa i3 Mk2. At the same time, I did not want to go through the complexity of some of the great solutions on Thingiverse. I needed a simple, reliable fix, that printed in a short period of time and did the job.

And here it is... It leverages the standard spool holders, fits right on top of them, and prevents the spool from falling off. . The small radius of the holder does not generate a lot of friction, so you should be in for a smooth ride.

Please print this file with the flat side facing down for best results.

As always - no warranties - use at your own risk. And enjoy.

comments.text: For anyone considering printing this, two things.  1.  Use supports for the notches regardless of the orientation you print at.  2.  I printed at .1mm layer height and spools spin quite a bit better than on the stock holder itself.  This is important because the mk2 suffers from Z tug, which means we have to calibrate every so often.  This print will result in less calibration over time because there is less strain on the Z axis when extruding.  When I say quite a bit less, I mean it is noticeable with your bare hand the difference in resistance.

title: HyperCube 3D Printer Dual brass bushing holder XY
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Dual brass bushing (outer diameter 10mm) holder for the X and Y axis for the HyperCube 3D Printer.
In the following a guide to reach the maximum smoothness on the rod. If you install the bushings cold it feels scratchy. WARNING: Don´t burn your fingers..
Installing one bushing first. Put it on the rod. Then put the second bushing on the rod and heat it up a little bit. Now push the end of the rod against something hard and heat resistant like the 2020 frame of your printer and push the printed bushing holder over the warm bushing. And try the smoothness on the rod. Sometimes you have to remove the other "cold" bushing and do the same like before.

Builds:
Dual bushing Y Axis V1.1: Hole position moved 0.4 mm per hole to the middle for better fitting

This 3D Model Minecraft Skin "creator" is the body of the minecraft character (print in clear for this to work how its intended) with printing all the little pixels of the character and placing them in the little carved out body. There are also rectangular blocks in the design made to go on the inside of the little avatar and keep the blocks from caving in. Make sure you place down at least the first layer of blocks before placing the support structure inside. :D

Note
You will need to create your own 0.5 x 0.5 x 0.5 cm cube by yourself because the cube was too little to be converted into an .stl file (atleast thats what i think what happened) Sorry for the inconvenience. These little cubes should be printed in the colour of the pixel of the character you intend to create for the "shell" or carved out body of the Minecraft character since they will be placed inside and viewable from the out side.
Bob-Omb from Super Mario. You ma need to cut the key and print it separately or print with supports.

title: Simple Auto Off for Tevo Tarantula

description.text:
This is my first upload to thingiverse so i appreciate your comments a lot :)

As i often print things over night or while i am not at home, i was looking for an easy solution to implement an auto-turn off function after the print is done.

This is my (primitive) approach:

See this gif for explanation:

iframe src="//giphy.com/embed/xUPGcfQvgSVlekUEIU" width="480" height="480" frameborder="0" class="giphy-embed" allowfullscreen="allowfullscreen"

via GIPHY

When the printer starts to move up during the print the hook moves to its active position. After the print is finished first the y-axis is homed (in oder to avoid crushing the print) and then the Z-axis is homed too. Shortly before reaching the z-home position the hook grabs the on/off switch an turns off the power for the printer and any other connected devices. Hope you like it :)

Tevo Tarantula

This is a case for my small o'scope, very tiny to stay in backpack. (I am a customer service engineer never in compagny's office.)

What you need :

  • 1 x Raspberry PI Compatible with Biscope probe.
  • 1 x Bitscope BS05U
  • 1 x Bitscope Hammerhead
  • 1 x Official Raspberry 7" touch screen
  • 1 x KCD1-104 power switch
  • 1 x Usb female plug 180°
  • 1 x 8Go SD card
  • 1 x USB battery bank or Usb Supply
  • 4 x M3x20mm
  • a lot of patience for an 11Hrs print!!

To reduce the volume of this o'scope I turned Upside Down the raspberry PI. (And gently twisted the video ribbon cable.)

Have fun!

title: Sujección filamento y centrado husillo Z "Anet A6"

description.text:
Pieza para Anet A6.
Es una guia para el filamento y además centra el husillo del eje Z.
El archivo STL es para el laterial izquierdo de la máquina, si se quiere para el otro lado simplemente basta con hacer una espejo (simetría) en CURA.

Yo la he puesto tanto en un sitio como en otro, porque siempre me viene el filamento de un lateral en la posición que yo tengo la máquina.

title: Anet A8 Extruder Fan Modification V2

description.text:
This is my second and better version of my Anet A8 Extruder Fan Modification.

Now you can open the extruder by rotate the fan to the right side.
You have to put the mod on the fan of the nozzle. Maybe you need screws wich are 5mm longer. I have luck and take my original screws.

The extruderfan and aluminium block have to be screwed with two 3x30mm screws and two 3mm nuts.
Additionally I use the Anet A8 Extruder Fan Spacer by AZDawg (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1798669) which I customized so the fan sits flush on the aluminium block.

Both Mod parts are screwd together with one 3x50mm screws and two 3mm nuts.

ATTENTION: It's important to sink in the holes of the aluminium block and the extruder block to make the screws flush with the blocks. Look at the pictures!

Maybe you have to check your extruder position, the aluminium block is supposed to be placed flat against the extruder.

EDIT: mod1V3 has stronger hinges

Printer:

Anet A8

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

Infill:

20%

Notes:

Support is only needed to the part wich comes on the fan for the nozzle

Instead of the 50mm screw. you may try printing out the pin found at https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2573278 and drilling out the hinge with a 5/32 bit.
And because others have asked:
The screws for the fan/heatsink is two flat head M3X30mm (or if you have them M3X35mm) screwed from the inside out with two 3mm nuts bolted on the outside of the fan.
The aluminum block and step motor are held in with two flat head M3x20mm screws.
The parts fan is held on with two M3x20mm screws (tight fit). depending on the cooler upgrades you are using, you may want a 25mm screw+washers there.

author: hadoko

title: Another JoyCon Frame
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
I tried a few of the other JoyCon frames and found that in one way or another they did not meet my needs. Either the controller did not fit well, were to fragile, or the part had issues printing.
So a made yet Another JoyCon Frame. Well, actually two frames. The first is meant to match the stock part in size, but without the hand grips. This fits nicely in most Switch cases, unlike the stock part. The second is larger with angled grips that also fits in your case. This features a grip along the back for comfort.

author: Limbusdev

description.text:
Saw the need for a stylus holder (it holds the stylus upside down to preserve the tip). Sits nice and tidy next to your Wacom Intuos tablet.

Really not much more to say about it Once again another utilitarian design. Please be sure to increase your top layers, in he shown image I am using 6. Otherwise you could be left with gaps / pillowing.. YUCK!

In the shown model I used Hatchbox blue glow in the dark PLA @ 1.75mm extruded at .1500 mm layer height @ 6000 mm using Prusa I3 MK2 with the titan extruder (increased MH to stepper and a multiplier of 2.26).

Enjoy!

author: bcman12358

description.text: A simple wall ring ... Ideal for suspending things

This is my first ever design.
I wanted a small adhesive trash bin in the bathroom, but unfortunately, those are hard to come by. IKEA has a small bin in the Stugvik collection for toothbrushes and such. This print is a cover for said bin. All you need is to add a small plastic bad to the inside and you have a small bin! :)
The cap handle is designed to go with the whole series concept.

Please comment any mistakes I made or improvements I could add.

author: kimmerkesdal

title: Hictop i3 Z Axis adjustable tool offset mount - Dual E3D - Precision

description.text:
Version 3.0 coming shortly. See last two pics.

Best printed in PETG if you have an all metal hot end for temp resistance to bed temp +60 degrees.
Am working on V2.1 of this mount with articulated 30mm fan mounts to adjust both height from bed and aim of airflow. Please msg me if interested.

This design required brass m3 expandable threaded inserts available from RS components.
15mm coil spring, 5 x M3 x 25mm, 2 x M3 x10mm.

Mount is mounted with M3 bolts through the pillow bearings from the back so the complete mount can be removed without changing the Z axis offset of the hotends.

Z offset from 0 is +/- 2mm.

Designed for dual E3D V6 hotends.

Please flip the clamp in your slicer to suit left / right side use.

Design can be modified to use M3 nuts in place of expanding inserts.

Hotend x offset in your slicer / marlin should be 32mm as a starting point before tuning.

Please like / comment.

description.text:

Converted model from obj to stl, partially fixed skirt in SketchUP and then finished repairing (making the object solid) with MS 3D Builder (Simplification and model Repair done by 3D Builder is easy to use with superb results)
